review.title: Stochastic Behavior of the Nonnegative Least Mean Fourth Algorithm for Stationary Gaussian Inputs and Slow Learning
review.abstract: Some system identification problems impose nonnegativity constraints on the parameters to estimate due to inherent physical characteristics of the unknown system. The nonnegative least-mean-square (NNLMS) algorithm and its variants allow to address this problem in an online manner. A nonnegative least mean fourth (NNLMF) algorithm has been recently proposed to improve the performance of these algorithms in cases where the measurement noise is not Gaussian. This paper provides a first theoretical analysis of the stochastic behavior of the NNLMF algorithm for stationary Gaussian inputs and slow learning. Simulation results illustrate the accuracy of the proposed analysis.

sections.heading: III. STATISTICAL ASSUMPTIONS
sections.text: The statistical analysis of any adaptive filter algorithm requires the use of statistical assumptions for feasibility. The analysis is based on the investigation of the behavior of the weighing terrorist vector, defined as W (n) = W (n) − W (8), and we use the following commonly used statistical assumptions: A.1) The input signal u (n) is stationary, zero mean and Gaussian.A.2) The input vector u (n) and the weight vector w (n) are independent of each other. A.3) The measuring noise z (n) is zero mean, i.e. it is independent of any other signal. In addition, it has a uniform probability density function, so that all odd moments of z (n) are equal to zero. A.4) The statistical dependence on w (n) w (n) w (n) w (n) and w (n) leads to a guess.

sections.heading: VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
sections.text: This section presents simulations in the context of system identification with non-negativity constraints to illustrate the accuracy of the models derived in sections IV and V. The impulse response w ² of the unknown system was of [0,8, 0,6, 0,5, 0,3, 0,2.0.1, − 0,1, − 0,3, − 0,6] >. The initial weight w (0) was equated to a vector drawn from the uniform distribution U ([0; 1]) and remains the same for all realizations. Both w ² and 0, − 0,3, − 0,6] The input was either a zero-mean white Gaussian signal of unit power or a correlated signal filtered by a first order system 34 by H (z) = 1 (1 − 0,5z − 1), which provides correlated inputs with unit variance. The above simulation setups are the same.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The NNLMF algorithm can outperform the NNLMS algorithm if the measurement noise is not of Gaussian origin. In this thesis, the mean and second behavior of the adaptive weights of the NNLMF algorithm for stationary Gaussian input signals and slow learning was investigated. Analysis was based on typical statistical assumptions and led to a recursive model for predicting the algorithm behavior. Simulation results showed an excellent agreement between the simulation results and the behavior predicted by the theoretical models. As the stability conditions for the NNLMF algorithm for convergence are difficult to analyze, we have shown that it depends on both the step size value and the initialization of the weights.

referenceMentions.context: ADAPTIVE filtering algorithms are widely used to address system identification problems in applications such as adaptive noise cancellation, echo cancellation, active noise control, and distributed learning [1]–[5].

ADAPTIVE filtering algorithms are widely used to address system identification problems in applications such as adaptive noise cancellation, echo cancellation, active noise control, and distributed learning [1]–[5].
Due to physical characteristics, some problems require the imposition of nonnegativity constraints on the parameters to estimate in order to avoid uninterpretable results [6].
, the nonnegative least-squares [7]–[10] and the nonnegative matrix factorization [11]–[15]).

The nonnegative least-mean-square (NNLMS) algorithm was derived in [16] to address online system identification problems subject to nonnegativity constraints.
Its convergence behavior was analyzed in [16], [17].
Its convergence behavior was analyzed in [16], [17].
Variants of the NNLMS algorithm were proposed in [18] and [19] to address specific robustness and convergence issues of NNLMS algorithm.
Variants of the NNLMS algorithm were proposed in [18] and [19] to address specific robustness and convergence issues of NNLMS algorithm.
The LMF algorithm was proposed in [20], where it was verified that it could outperform the LMS algorithm in the presence of non-Gaussian measurement noise.
This desirable property has led to a series of studies about the convergence behaviors of the LMF algorithm and some of its variants [21]–[31].
This desirable property has led to a series of studies about the convergence behaviors of the LMF algorithm and some of its variants [21]–[31].
Recently, a nonnegative LMF (NNLMF) algorithm was proposed in [32] to improve the performance of the NNLMS algorithm under non-Gaussian measurement noise.

It was shown in [32] that, when compared to the NNLMS algorithm, the NNLMF algorithm can lead to faster convergence speed and equivalent steady-state performance, and to improved steady-state performance for the same convergence speed.
The results shown in [32] were exclusively based on Monte Carlo simulations.
It is known that the study of the stability of the LMF algorithm is relatively complex [22], [23].

metadata.abstractText: Some system identification problems impose nonnegativity constraints on the parameters to estimate due to inherent physical characteristics of the unknown system. The nonnegative least-mean-square (NNLMS) algorithm and its variants allow to address this problem in an online manner. A nonnegative least mean fourth (NNLMF) algorithm has been recently proposed to improve the performance of these algorithms in cases where the measurement noise is not Gaussian. This paper provides a first theoretical analysis of the stochastic behavior of the NNLMF algorithm for stationary Gaussian inputs and slow learning. Simulation results illustrate the accuracy of the proposed analysis.
